fields.title: De fundamentele natuurconstanten
fields.text:
De schaling van de natuurwetten wordt gegeven door de waarden van de fundamentele natuurconstanten zoals de lichtsnelheid, de fijnstructuurconstante, de constante van Planck, etc. Geen enkele natuurkundige theorie voorspelt de waarde van deze natuurconstanten. Het cosmologisch principe, een van de uitgangspunten van de Algemene Relativiteitstheorie, veronderstelt dat het heelal er voor alle waarnemers hetzelfde uitziet; dus, de waarde van een natuurconstante is constant en overal hetzelfde als ART klopt. Dankzij de huidige waarden van de natuurconstanten leven wij in een heelal waar organisch leven heeft kunnen ontstaan. Een kleine verandering in een constante had al "fataal" kunnen zijn. Sommigen menen dat er vele heelallen zijn, ieder met een eigen set natuurconstanten.

Met de waarnemingen van verre objecten (bijvoorbeeld quasars) kan men in principe de waarde van sommige natuurconstanten meten als functie van de tijd. Als de waarde sinds de Oerknal veranderd is, betekent dat natuurlijk dat deze constante niet constant is.

fields.title: Experimental projects with the Anton Pannekoek Observatory telescopes
fields.text:
The following projects can be done. Further details can be provided by Huib Henrichs.
 
Photometry:
- Exoplanet transits + modeling
- Pulsating stars + modeling
- Cluster distance and age determination
- Monitoring optical counterparts of X-ray or other transients down to V = 18
 
Spectroscopy:
- Exoplanet orbits (tau Boo)
- Binary orbits
- Atmospheres of pulsating stars
- Monitoring variable H alpha emission of Be stars
- Temperature and electron density in planetary nebulae
- Redshifts of galaxies
 
Imaging:
- Narrow band imaging of bright nebulae
- Broad band imaging of galaxies

fields.title: The rapid variability of the black hole binary Cygnus X-1
fields.text:
The bright x-ray radiation observed from accreting black holes in our
Galaxy provides the opportunity to directly observe the most extreme
predictions of General Relativity. Since the region dominating the
energy release is only around 100km accross, it is impossible to
directly image. Instead, inferences about the accretion geometry must
be made by studying the energy and time dependence of the observed
radiation. This project will involve using data from the Rossi x-ray
timing explorer (RXTE) to determine which regions of the accretion
flow of Cygnus X-1 produce rapid variability and which remain
stable. This information places important constraints on the accretion
geometry, which are vital if we are to understand the physical
processes at work in the immediate vicinity of a black hole.

Supervisors:  Dr Adam Ingram and Prof. Michiel van der Klis

fields.title: Mapping the monsters: using X-ray echoes to get close to black holes
fields.text: The accretion of matter on to a black hole is one of the most efficient sources of power in the universe, and is capable of producing enormous electromagnetic luminosities as well as launching relativistic jets of particles to huge distances.   If we want to fully understand the source of this power and how matter behaves in the enormous gravity close to the black hole, we need to obtain pictures of the regions closest to the black hole.  However, these regions appear smaller than microarcseconds on the sky and are impossible to image in the conventional way.  Now a new technique called 'X-ray reverberation mapping' promises a breakthrough in studying the regions closest to the black hole.  The technique measures the delay caused by the light-travel time from the X-ray continuum source close to the black hole, to the disc of infalling matter that feeds it, by measuring time-lags between variations of the continuum and the corresponding variations of the reflection spectrum from the disc.  These time-lags can be translated into physical distances (assuming light-travel times), resulting in a picture of the emitting region showing the location of the disc and continuum source, which can also be used to study the effects of strong gravity on the space-time close to the black hole.  For this project, you will learn about X-ray reverberation mapping by surveying the recent papers on the topic and investigating  how this powerful technique can open a new window on to black holes.

fields.title: Fast changes in the X-ray oscillations from black holes
fields.text: The region closest to an accreting black hole emits powerful X-rays. We can study this radiation with orbiting space telescopes and use the observations to probe the behaviour of matter in the presence of strong gravity. The X-rays we observe vary strongly over a whole range of timescales (from milliseconds to years) often showing quasi-periodic signals. These signals promise to reveal a wealth of information, testing predictions made by General Relativity and help uncover underlying properties of the black hole such as mass and spin. Clearly, they must be linked to the very fast (near-light-speed) motions relativity predicts for matter that is orbiting under the influence of the enormous gravity of a black hole at such close range. Currently however their precise origin is not well understood. This project would use observations taken by NASA's Rossi X-ray Timing Explorer satellite to explore the changes in both frequency and amplitude of these quasi-periodic oscillations (QPOs) over short timescales (~seconds). Previously these features have mostly been studied by averaging over whole observations with lengths of a few kiloseconds, smearing out fast evolution occurring on shorter timescales and losing valuable information on how and why the changes happen. These results will then be used to make comparisons between different observations, in an attempt to better understand what underlying process drives the evolution in the QPOs.

fields.title: The effect of cosmic rays on star formation
fields.text: Galaxies are not static beasts, but rather they are made up of gas, dust, electromagnetic fields and stars (among other things).   There is a constant recycling of material as gas condenses to form stars, then those stars in turn age and in some cases go supernova, enriching their surroundings with metals, and the process starts again with different initial conditions.   Depending on what sorts of stars are nearby, the molecular gas where stars are born will also be ionised by stellar UV photons, changing the gas state and affecting subsequent star formation.  Furthermore, supernovae drive shocks into the surrounding interstellar medium (ISM), in the process accelerating particles to high energy, called “cosmic rays”, which can also ionise the surrounding ISM.   Finally, in some cases, a massive star in a binary system will end up as a black hole or neutron star that can accrete of its companion, initiating the formation of relativistic jets of plasma that can also accelerate cosmic rays.   Over the last decade it has become increasingly clear that the ionisation as well as collisional heating via cosmic rays also effects star formation, along with photo-ionisation, and this is a very interesting and emerging field at the cutting edge of astrophysics, astroparticle physics and astrochemistry.   The students will have rather free reign to explore the more recent literature, with a few guiding questions, in order to build a picture of our current understanding of the effects of “cosmic ray feedback” on star formation in galaxies.

fields.title: X-ray spectroscopy of 30DorC
fields.text: This is a large shell (48pc radius) in the LMC. It shows evidence for X-ray synchrotron radiation, which is surprising as it indicates high shock velocities, which are not suspected in such a large (and hence old) shell. There is a lot of unanalysed XMM Newton data of this shell. The project is the reduction of these data, and fitting spectral models to spectra of different regions

fields.title: The jet in the supernova remnant Cas A
fields.text:
The bright SNR Cas A has two opposite jets, which happen to be nearly in the plane of the sky. The northwestern
jet is most pronounced and extends to at least twice the radius of the shell. The tip of the jet has been analysed
in X-rays, but with puzzling results. Moreover, there is new data available. For this project the student will extract
(Chandra) X-ray spectra from the jet region, and fit SPEX models to it, to determine the density and other plasma
properties of the tip of the jet. The idea is to get a better idea of what caused the creation of the jets.

fields.title: Observations of low-level accretion onto strongly magnetized neutron star
fields.text: Accretion onto strongly magnetized neutron star has been studied in detail. However, nearly all studies have been performed for high to very high accretion rates. Recently, we have obtained a large data set on systems in which the accretion rate is several orders of magnitude lower. The data have been obtained using the NASA X-ray satellite Swift. The student will learn about accretion processes and physics on strongly magnetized neutron star and will learn the basic skills needed to analysis such satellite date.

fields.title: Thermonuclear explosions on neutron stars:  how do they get their spots?
fields.text:
Type I X-ray bursts are thermonuclear explosions triggered by unstable burning in the
oceans of accreting neutron stars. Intrinsically interesting nuclear phenomena, they are
also important as probes of dense matter physics and the strong gravity, high magnetic
field environment of the neutron star surface. The basic cause of bursts, an imbalance
between nuclear heating and radiative cooling in the accreted material, can be explained using
simple one-dimensional calculations. The past decade, however, has revealed major
complexities that can no longer be understood within the context of such simple models.
The development of unusually bright spots on the burning surface (known as burst oscillations) in around 10% of
bursts, for reasons that remain unknown, now requires us to consider flame spreading and
multi-dimensional effects. Serious discrepancies between expected and observed burst
recurrence times imply a role for turbulent mixing and quasi-stable burning between
bursts. And the highly atypical properties of bursts and burst oscillations from accreting
pulsars suggest an important dynamical role for the magnetic field.

Two possible projects exist, both aiming to answer fundamental questions
about the burst process and the development of burst oscillations.  The students will be able to use a large pre-prepared burst database, and a suite of established analysis software, to carry out their projects.  Specific projects include:  

1. Can burst oscillations reveal the orbit? The spots that develop
during bursts can be used to measure the spin of the neutron star to
within a few Hz.   The student will investigate whether they can also
be used to reveal the binary orbital parameters.  In many stars we
have no other way of measuring spin or orbital parameters, which are
critical to models of stellar structure and evolution.  

2.  How fast can a spot move?   The spots that develop during X-ray
bursts are often likened to thermonuclear hurricanes.  If so then we
might expect to find spots that move around more rapidly on the
surface, in addition to the slow-moving kind already discovered.  The
student will carry out a search for these more rapidly moving weather
patterns.

fields.title: Observations of low-level accretion in the neutron star transient XTE J1701–462
fields.text: In neutron star low-mass X-ray binaries (NS-LMXBs) matter is transferred from a low-mass star to an accretion disk surrounding a weakly magnetized neutron star. Many of these systems are transient, alternating between outbursts (during which matter is transferred onto the neutron star at a high rate) and quiescence (during which little or no accretion onto the neutron star takes place). In recent years it has become clear that many NS-LXMBs show low-level accretion activity during periods of quiescence; however, accretion of this sort remains poorly understood. In this project the student will study sporadic low-level accretion flares in the quiescent NS-LMXB XTE J1701–462 using data from the Swift and XMM-Newton X-ray satellites.

fields.title: Powerful winds in X-ray binaries
fields.text: Highly ionized winds are often observed in X-ray binaries systems. In low-mass X-ray binaries they are believed to play an important role in regulating the accretion/ejection mechanism. Winds are best studied through X-ray spectroscopy, which reveals the ionization state, the thickness and the velocity of the wind. These characteristics are variable in time and this can help understanding the geometry of the plasma in the system. This project is about a bright X-ray binary, recently observed by the HETG spectrometer on board the Chandra X-ray observatory. The student will analyze the time variable X-ray spectrum and the variation in the gas, with the goal of determining its physical characteristics.

fields.title: A triple origin for blue stragglers in M67
fields.text: Binaries and systems of higher multiplicity (triples, quadruples, etc.) are commonly found in our Galaxy. Recent theoretical considerations indicate that triples consisting of a close inner binary and a far-away companion could play a key role in the formation of blue stragglers, an exotic class of "rejuvenated" stars that somehow managed to look much younger than other stars in their (coeval) population. In this project the student will analyse high-resolution optical spectra of at least two such stragglers in the old open cluster M67 that are known to be long-period (in excess of a few years) binaries. The goal is to look for signatures of an inner close binary or other clues to these stragglers' formation history. The presence of a close binary would also offer an explanation for the X-rays that have been observed from these systems.
fields.contact: Dr Maureen van den Berg, M.C.vandenBerg@uva.nl

fields.title: Interactive data mining and data visualization in astronomy
fields.text:
Abstract: Big data, data mining and data visualization are fast growing research areas in many facets of society. With the current generation of astronomical telescopes and instrumentation, and those planned for the near-future, big data will become increasingly important for astronomy as well. During this project, the student will get an introduction to this subject using a relatively small, but representative data base on accreting neutron stars and black holes to create flexible, interactive analysis tools to be used for data mining and data visualization on this astronomical data base. The student will partly work at API and partly at CWI to obtain the required skills (e.g., python scripting; Structured Query Language (SQL); required statistical methods).

Supervisors: Rudy Wijnands (Anton Pannekoek Institute; API), Bart Scheers (Centrum Wiskunde & Informatica; CWI)

fields.title: What is known about the chemical composition of rocky exoplanets?
fields.text: This is a literature project.  The students should go through the literature and put together everything that is known about the chemical composition of exoplanets.  This will be papers with theoretical modes as well as observational studies of exoplanetary atmospheres.

fields.title: Where does the water on the Earth come from?
fields.text: This is a literature study:  Over the years, various ideas have popped up on how water was delivered to the Earth, how much water there is anyway, and if we can get information about the origin of the water.  The students will conduct a literature study to collect and organise this information.

fields.title: Ice emission features from T Tauri disks
fields.text: Water ice has emission features at a number of wavelengths.  In particular, there are features at 44 and 62 microns.  These emission features are interesting because they are sensitive to the thermal history of the ice - was it formed at high temperatures and then cooled down, or the other way round?  Such information will be important to understand the history of the building block of planets and comets.  In this project, we want to model the disks of T Tauri stars and see under what circumstances this emission feature will be visible in observations, in particular with the planned SPICA/SAFARI mission.  The project consists mainly of a parameter study with a state of the art disk modelling and radiative transfer code.  Basic abilities with a computer like running basic UNIX commands and working with plotting software are a requirement for this project.

fields.title: De grote kern van Mercurius
fields.text:
Eén van de bijzondere eigenschappen van de planeet Mercurius is dat hij relatief een zeer grote, zware kern heeft. Er zijn verschillende verklaringen hiervoor gegeven, zoals een botsing met een ander object dat een deel van de buitenmantel liet verdwijnen of zijn ontstaansgeschiedenis op korte afstand van de zon. Dure ruimtesondes richten zich m.n. op deze laatste mogelijke oorzaak, in de hoop om meer over de vorming van het zonnestelsel te weten te komen, maar wat als er alleen maar ooit een stuk van Mercurius afgevlogen is? Met dit project willen we een inzicht krijgen in hoeverre er een zinvolle vraagstelling aan het ruimteonderzoek ten grondslag ligt. 

De werkzaamheden richten zich op een aantal vragen: 
*waaruit blijkt dat de kern van Mercurius een bijzondere plaats inneemt
*wat zijn de essentiële kenmerken van de theorieën die dit proberen te verklaren
*hoe waarschijnlijk is de botsingshypothese
*welke metingen zijn hiertoe gedaan door satellieten en tot welke conclusies leiden die
*welke metingen zullen door volgende ruimtesondes uitgevoerd worden

fields.title: Radiële snelheden uit spectra van OB sterren
fields.text:
Dankzij het Doppler effect kunnen we radiële snelheden bepalen uit sterspectra. Voor alle noordelijke O-B5 sterren (tot een zekere magnitudelimiet) waarvoor nog geen radiële snelheden bekend waren zijn er echellespectra verkregen die een meting van de radiële snelheid mogelijk maken. Daarmee zijn die speciale gevallen te herkennen die een abnormaal grote ruimtelijke snelheid hebben (zgn. Wegloopsterren, of Runaway Stars) als gevolg van gebeurtenis in hun verleden, zoals een supernova explosie waarbij een dubbelster ontbonden werd of dynamische processen in jonge stergroepen. 

Het gaat er in dit project om:
*een procedure voor de analyse van deze sterspectra op te zetten (m.b.v. het softwarepakket IRAF)
*spectrale analyse uit te voeren voor een zinvolle subgroup van de O-B5 sterren
*radiële snelheden te bepalen m.b.v. vergelijkspectra
*bijzondere gevallen te identificeren die kwalificeren als Wegloopsterren

fields.title: Het totale aantal supernovaresten in ons sterrenstelsel
fields.text:
Een supernova (SN) is waarneembaar gedurende een tijdsperiode van een paar maanden tot een paar jaar, maar de uitdijende supernovarest (SNR) die hij vervolgens nalaat is dat voor een veel langere tijd (10^3 – 3.10^4 jaar). SNae in ons eigen Melkwegstelsel zijn waargenomen sinds ca. 2000 jaar geleden, echter bijna alleen in de wijdere zonsomgeving. De studie van SNRs geeft ons een vollediger beeld voor het Melkwegstelsel: het zijn langer durende verschijnselen en zij zijn prominent op golflengten die beter dan optische ons stelsel penetreren (radio, röntgen). 

Waar we optisch een handvol historische SNae kennen, wordt ons sterrenstelsel beter bestreken door de uitgebreide catalogus van SNRs die op grond van radiosurveys is opgesteld. We willen deze catalogus analyseren met als uiteindelijk doel het totale aantal SNRs in ons stelsel te bepalen. Het gaat dan vooral om de verdeling van SNRs over het Melkwegstelsel en om de vraag hoeveel objecten wij missen als we verder dan de zon gaan. Een dergelijk onderzoek draagt bij tot schattingen van het totale aantal van SNae die in de laatste ~10^4 jaar in ons sterrenstelsel afgingen. 

De werkzaamheden omvatten zoal: 
*verkrijgen en manipuleren van de voornaamste radiocatalogus
*schatting van afstanden van de SNRs
*vergelijking van de radiocatalogus met catalogi op andere golflengten
*analyseer de ruimtelijke verdeling van de SNRs, in samenhang met de structuur van het Melkwegstelsel
*bepaal volledigheid van de catalogus
*onderzoek schattingen van de leeftijd van de SNRs
*afleiding van de frequentie waarmee SNae in ons stelsel plaatsvinden
*onderzoek diverse subselecties, zoals SNae Ia versus andere SN typen

fields.title: The most massive binaries in the Milky Way and in the Large Magellanic Cloud
fields.text:
- Context
Massive stars are rare but their importance in astrophysics bely their numbers. Through their energetic life and death they exert a strong influence on their environment. They are the progenitors of neutron stars and stellar-mass blackholes and are believed to be responsible of the reionization of the early Universe. Our understanding of their formation and evolution remains however unsatisfactory, especially for the most massive members of the class (initial mass > 50 Msun). Current theories eagerly need high quality observational constraints. 

- Project
Binaries offer astrophysical laboratories of choice because they provide direct constraints on some of the fundamental properties of the stars. In this context, we have collected multi-epoch XSHOOTER optical and NIR spectroscopy of some of the most massive binaries in the Milky Way and in the Large Magellanic Cloud, with system masses around 150 Msun and beyond. The candidate is expected to analyse the data of one or several of these objects to constrain the physical and orbital properties of the binary components and to evaluate their evolutionary status. Expected steps in the analysis include :

- data reduction
- companion signature lookup
- spectral typing
- spectral disentangling/reconstruction
- orbital solution determination
- atmosphere modelling 
- comparison with evolutionary models 
 
The final aim is to obtain unprecedented constraints on the physical and evolutionary properties of these objects to confront state-of-the art theoretical models. 

The candidate is expected to have an interest in stellar astrophysics. Computer literacy and the knowledge of one  programming language are assets. The project will be performed in close collaboration with Profs. Lex Kaper and Alex de Koter from Amsterdam as well as with collaborators abroad.

fields.title: Tracing the gas component in planet forming regions using Graphics Card computing
fields.text:
- Context
During the process of star formation a lot of material is left in the immediate surroundings. This material is present in the form of an accretion disk rotating the newly born star. It is inside this accretion disk that planet formation is thought to occur. In the early phases the disk is still very massive and rich in gas. While most of the mass is contained in the gas component, the radiation, and many of the observables are dominated by the solid state dust component. In order to trace the gas component, which is responsible for the dynamics and for the formation of large planets, we need to be able to understand, model and analyze the gas component. Current computational methods to trace molecular species in the gas, like CO or water, take too long for large scale model grid computer simulations. The aim of this project is to speed this up by a considerable fraction by using the massive parallel computing power stored in modern graphics card computing units (GPUs).

- Project
In this project we want to explore the possibilities to significantly reduce the computation time for raytracing the gas line diagnostics in protoplanetary disks using graphics card computing. Using the massive parallel possibilities of modern graphics card would allow us to simultaneously trace many rays in a disk image. Graphics cards have actually been designed to be particularly good at raytracing, which is exactly what we need to do. Possible components of the project:

  • modeling of radiative transfer in protoplanetary disks (using existing programs)
  • mastering the art of graphics card programming
  • writing/adjusting a software module to do raytracing on the multiple cpus of a graphics card
  • comparison with observations of protoplanetary disks

Along the way, the candidate will learn about the chemistry, geometry and dynamics of protoplanetary disks and help to develop the diagnostics needed to interpret observations.

The final aim is to construct a computer program that can be run on a single computer and is able to compute the line diagnostics for protoplanetary disks on a timescale suitable for large scale model computations.
